title: Introducing Yourself
description: Learn how to introduce yourself in Portuguese, including your name, age, nationality, and profession.
objectives: Say your name and ask others their names

vocabulary.english: My name is / I call myself

vocabulary.notes: Men say encantado, women say encantada
Same form for masculine and feminine

grammar.title: The Verb 'Ser' (To Be)
grammar.content: The verb 'ser' is used for permanent characteristics like nationality, profession, and identity. Conjugation: Eu sou, Tu és, Ele/Ela é, Nós somos, Eles/Elas são.
examples: Ele é médico. (He is a doctor.)

grammar.title: Expressing Age
grammar.content: In Portuguese, you 'have' years rather than 'are' years old. Use 'Tenho + number + anos'.
examples: Tenho vinte anos. (I am 20 years old.)
Ela tem trinta e cinco anos. (She is 35 years old.)
Quantos anos tens? (How old are you?)

grammar.title: Gender Agreement in Professions
grammar.content: Most professions change ending based on gender. Masculine typically ends in -o, feminine in -a. Some professions are invariable.

exercises.question: How do you formally introduce yourself saying 'My name is Maria'?
exercises.explanation: 'Chamo-me Maria' is the formal way to say 'My name is Maria' or literally 'I call myself Maria'.

exercises.question: Complete: ____ vinte e três anos. (I am 23 years old)
exercises.explanation: In Portuguese, you use 'tenho' (I have) to express age, not 'sou' (I am).

exercises.question: If you're a male saying 'Nice to meet you', which do you say?
exercises.explanation: Men say 'encantado' (pleased to meet you). Women say 'encantada'.

exercises.question: How do you say 'I am Portuguese' (male speaker)?
exercises.explanation: 'Sou português' means 'I am Portuguese' for a male speaker. A female would say 'Sou portuguesa'.

exercises.question: Which verb do you use to talk about your profession?
exercises.explanation: Use 'ser' (sou) for professions because it's a permanent characteristic. Example: 'Sou professor'.

culturalNotes.title: Formal vs Informal Introductions
culturalNotes.content: In formal situations, use 'Chamo-me' and the polite 'você'. With friends, you can say 'Eu sou' or just your name. Young people often skip formalities and jump straight to first names.

culturalNotes.title: Handshakes and Kisses
culturalNotes.content: In business, a firm handshake is standard. Among friends and family, two kisses on the cheek (starting right) is common. Men typically shake hands with each other.
